INC anniversary bilang non-working holiday, pasado sa Kamara

INAPRUBAHAN na sa ikatlo at huling pagbasa ang panukalang batas na ibilang na special non-working holiday ang anibersaryo ng Iglesia ni Cristo (INC).

Batay sa House Bill 5686, tuwing anibersaryo ng Iglesia Ni Cristo na July 27 ay idedeklara itong non-working holiday.

Ang pagpapasa sa panukala ay isinagawa kaalinsabay ng ika-103 taong anibersaryo ng INC na inaprubahan ng may 242 kongresista.

Ang panukalang ito ay pinagsama-samang panukala nina Reps. Winston Castelo (PDP-Laban, Quezon City); Alfred Vargas (PDP-Laban, QC); Eugene de Vera (ABS Partylist); Gil P. Acosta (NP, Palawan); Gus Tambunting (PDP-Laban, Parañaque City) at Romeo Acop (LP, Antipolo City).

Sinabi ni Castelo na inaamyendahan ng HB 5686 ang Republic Act No. 9645 o mas kilala bilang Commemoration of the Founding Anniversary of Iglesia Ni Cristo Act, sa pamamagitan ng pagdedeklara ng July 27 bilang non-working holiday.

Paliwanag ni Castelo, chairman ng House Committee on Metro Manila Development, ito’y upang mabigyan ng pagkakataon ang mga Pilipino na miembro ng INC na maipagdiwang ang anibersaryo tuwing July 27.

Samantala, naipasa na sa Committee on Rules ang House Resolution 1163 na nagpapahatid ng pagbati sa ika-103 anibersaryo ng Iglesia Ni Cristo nitong nagdaang July 27, 2017 at ang House Resolution 1167 na nagpapahatid naman ng pagbati sa walong taong matagumpay na pangunguna ni Iglesia Ni Cristo Executive Minister Eduardo V. Manalo.

column31: PREPARING FOR THE 18TH CONGRESS 03 June 2019 06:45:46 PM Rep. Manuel Jose Dalipe (2nd District, Zamboanga City), chairman of the House Committee on the Welfare of Children, in a hearing on Monday, requested resource persons representing different government agencies and non-governmental organizations (NGOs) to submit their comments to the Committee Secretariat regarding House Bill Nos. 533, 2259, 3999 and 5709 authored by Reps. Ruwel Peter Gonzaga (2nd District, Compostela Valley), Anna Katrina Enverga (1st District, Quezon), Maximo Rodriguez Jr. (2nd District, Cagayan de Oro City), and Alfred Vargas (5th District, Quezon City), respectively. HB 533 seeks to establish a national center for missing children while HB 2259 aims to provide for day care centers rehabilitation and improvement program and creating day care centers rehabilitation and improvement fund. HB 3999 seeks to establish a crisis center for street children in all cities and municipalities in the National Capital Region and in every highly urbanized city in the country while HB 5709 seeks to establish a crisis center for street children in every region of the Philippines. Dalipe said the Secretariat is now formulating the proposed legislative agenda and approval of the incoming chairperson and members of the 18th Congress. Among the stakeholders who attended the meeting were Department of Justice Senior Assistant State Prosecutor Ma. Nerissa Carpio, Department of Social Welfare and Development Protection Services Bureau OIC Division Chief Miramel Laxa-Garcia, DSWD Planning Officer Joshua Matipo, Commission on Human Rights Policy Researcher Aaron Cayabyab, Arlyne Fernandez of the Virlanie Foundaiton, Catherine Scerri of Bahay Tuluyan, Micah Denise del Mundo of the Early Childhood Care and Development Council, and children from Child Rights Network. / Caption by Ma. column31: Mga Ka-ANGKLA, ang ating kinatawan at tinig sa Kongreso ay nagtrabaho para sa Pilipinong marino para sa pagkakaroon ng Single Maritime Administration sa pagpapatupad ng mga STCW requirements. Hayaan niyo po sanang ilahad ko sa baba ang mga dahilan kung bakit kailangan nating magkaroon ng Single Maritime Administration sa ating bansa: 1. Sa kasalukuyan, ang Pilipinas lamang and bansa na walang isang Maritime Administration na nagpapalakad sa pagpatupad ng mga alituntunin ng IMO lalo na ang STCW. Sa Pilipinas, marami tayong ahensya na nangangasiwa para sa mga panga-ngailangan ng mga marino katulad ng CHED para sa Edukasyon ng Marino, PRC para sa pabibigay ng pagsusulit para ang isang Pilipino ay mabigyan ng lisensya, MARINA para mag issue ng Seaman’s Book at COP's, NTC para sa Radio Certificate at ilan pang ibang ahensya. 2. Nang dahil sa madaming ahensyang ito, napuna na ng EMSA na wala ngang iisang maritime administration para sa mga marino kaya’t sila ay nag-audit muli sa ating bansa noong nakaraang October. Ang EMSA audit na ito ay maaaring mag-dulot ng malaking kawalan sa atin dahil posibleng mawalan ng hanap-buhay ang mga 80,000 na Pilipinong kasalukuyang nakasakay sa mga European ships, kung sakaling mag desisyon ang EMSA na hindi sang-ayon sa STCW ang ating pamumuno dahil sa kawalan ng isang maritime administration . 3. Ang pagpuna ng EMSA sa kakulangang ito ay hindi na bago. Ito ay nagsimula pa ilang taon na rin ang nakalipas, kaya’t noong April 2012, si Presidente Noynoy Aquino ay gumawa ng paraan sa pamamagitan ng pag-issue ng EO 75. Ito ang pangunahang tugon n g ating gobyerno noong nakaraang taon, sa mga katanungan ng EMSA at ng ibang mga bansa kung sino ba talaga ang ahensya ng gobyerno ng Pilipinas na may pananagutan at resposibilidad sa pamamahala ng edukasyon, pagsusuri at pabibigay ng kaukulang dokumento sa isang Pilipinong Marino upang mag qualify at makapagtrabaho sa barko sa iba’t ibamg lugar sa mundo. 4. Para mapaigting ang layunin ng EO 75 at tuluyang maging batas, Single Maritime Administration Act ang kasagutan. 5. Marami ang nagtatanong kung ito ba ay nangangahulugang magtatayo ng panibagong ahensya kapag ang panakulang ito ay ganap na maging batas? Ang sagot po ay hindi. Ang layunin nito ay mag-talaga ng isang administration sa pamumuno at pangangalaga ng MARINA. Ang MARINA ay buo na at pag naipasa ang batas, sila lamang ay aatasang na gampanan ang karagdagang tungkulin na maipatupad ang nararapat na sistema ayon sa STCW. Ang pagbabaggo ay ang pagdaragdag ng ilang taong mahuhusay at eksperto sa ahensya ng MARINA na tutulong masakatuparan ang mga ito. Ang pagbubuklod ng lahat ng ahensya ay mangangahulugan na sa isang opisina na lang ang pupuntahan ng mga marino at ito ay matagal ng inaasam asam na ma isakatuparan. Kailangan nating unahin na magkaroon ng batas para hindi na maulit ang paibaibang patakaran para sa ating mga marino. Maaring marami ang nagdududa sa kakayanan ng MARINA subalit dapat natin silang bigyan ng pagkakataon at ating ding tulungan dahil ang lahat ng ito ay para sa ikabubuti ng ating industriya. Ang layunin ng Angkla at ng ating kinatawan na si Congressman Jess Manalo ay para maiwasan ang pagkalito at pagkabagal ng mga proseso sa pagkuha ng mga lisensya at sertipiko ng mga marinpong Pilipino, at higit sa lahat ang makasigurong ang ating mga proseso at standards ay naaayon sa STCW, na siyang tutulong upang tuluyan ng mawala ang banta ng EMSA at EU na hindi taggapin ang mga dokumento ng Pilipinong Marino para makapag trabaho sa mga barkong pag aari ng EU. Ang mga marino ay tunay na bagong bayani ng ating bansa na tumutulong para mapaunlad ang ating ekomiya. Kami ay humihingi ng inyong suporta at pagmamatyag para sama sama nating iaangat ang kalidad ng ahensya at makatugon sa mga alituntunin ng STCW. Ang tanging hangarin ng ANGKLA para sa mga marino ay masigurado ang tuloy tuloy na trabaho, mapadali ang proseso ng pagsasaayos ng dokumento at mapanatili ang pagiging numero uno sa buong mundo. Sama sama sana nating suportahan at tulungan and ating industriya. Lubos na sumasainyo, Capt. Ronaldo SJ. Enrile Vice Chairman - ANGKLA

column31: HOUSE CONDUCTS ROUNDTABLE DISCUSSION ON “HOW TO BE A GENDER-RESPONSIVE LEGISLATOR” Committed to achieving a more gender-responsive Congress, the House Committee on Women and Gender Equality chaired by Bukidnon Rep. Ma. Lourdes Acosta-Alba held a roundtable discussion Tuesday, on “How to be a gender-responsive legislator." The discussion aimed to address and eliminate discriminatory laws against women and girls, finetune legislative priorities, as well as identify gaps in the legal framework. The online discussion was organized by the committee, in partnership with the Philippine Commission on Women (PCW) and the International Development Law Organization (IDLO) to discuss the roadmap entitled, “Equality in Law for Women and Girls by 2030: A Multi-stakeholder Strategy for Accelerated Action.” The roadmap was launched by the UN Women in March 2019. IDLO Consultant Gettie Sandoval presented a study on the analysis of laws in the country from a gender perspective. She said there are women-specific laws consistent with the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW) but there are still inconsistencies and gaps in previous laws with the Magna Carta on Women. The research also revealed there are laws with prevailing gender stereotypes that need to be addressed. Meanwhile, Deputy Speaker Bernadette Herrera-Dy said the country maintains its post as the most gender-equal country in Asia, closing 80 percent of the labor force gap, as women outnumbered men in senior leadership roles as well as in the professional and technical fields. Herrera-Dy also encouraged stakeholders to put forward amendments on the antiquated laws that need change for a better, more gender-responsive and balanced legislation. Acosta-Alba urged legislators to continue building networks and alliances in crafting and passing important legislation. Acosta-Alba then announced that the committee would launch the handbook on "How to be a Gender-Responsive Legislator", which was developed by the PCW, once sessions resume in May. The handbook aims to guide legislators in taking a critical look at the lawmaking processes, as well as aiding them in refining proposed measures towards gender-responsiveness and promotion of women’s rights. column31: HOUSE KICKS OFF WOMEN’S MONTH 2021 CELEBRATION House Members, Secretariat officials and employees, as well as congressional staff gathered on Monday for a flag-raising ceremony to commence the celebration of Women’s Month 2021. This year's theme is: "Women Make Change Work for Women.” The ceremony was hosted by the Committee on Women and Gender Equality, chaired by Bukidnon Rep. Maria Lourdes Acosta-Alba. Acosta-Alba's inspirational message was delivered by Rep. Jocelyn Sy Limkaichong (1st District, Negros Oriental) on her behalf. Acosta-Alba urged that women must take on more leadership roles in society as she encouraged them to speak out boldly wherever they are. “We, women, should lead not only at the top levels of government, but also in communities and in our own homes. These are where a lot of decisions are made. It is through making decisions that we can effect positive change. We should never be afraid to speak out. Huwag tayong mananahimik. We have our own voices. We should never lose them,” she said. Acosta-Alba then urged her fellow lady leaders in communities and in the government to work together towards making a difference in the country by helping women, especially those who have gravely suffered due to the pandemic. “Despite all of the challenges we face, huwag tayong panghihinaan ng loob. We, women, are naturally strong and resilient. Kakayanin natin ang mga problemang ating haharapin. The first step is for us to know our worth. We are very capable. Hindi tayo babae lang. Babae tayo,” added Acosta-Alba. Meanwhile, Deputy Speaker Bernadette Herrera-Dy called for the commitment of the House Members and workforce to expedite the passage of measures that would bring about change and equality for the benefit of Filipinas. “Women are truly a force to be reckoned with. Women are strong and formidable yet loving and emphatic. Kaya mas lalong dapat ang Pilipina ay protektahan, bigyan ng dignidad, at bigyan ng kahalagahan sa sariling bansa,” Herrera-Dy said. All attendees were required to submit their Health Declaration Forms and negative Antigen test results. Wearing of face mask and face shields as well as practicing social distancing were also observed throughout the ceremony. The proposed “Handog sa mga Bayaning Lumaban Kontra COVID-19 Act,” principally authored by Deputy Speaker Michael Romero Ph.D., would exempt all medical front-liners from paying 25 percent of income tax. INC anniversary bilang non-working holiday, pasado sa Kamara

INAPRUBAHAN na sa ikatlo at huling pagbasa ang panukalang batas na ibilang na special non-working holiday ang anibersaryo ng Iglesia ni Cristo (INC).

Batay sa House Bill 5686, tuwing anibersaryo ng Iglesia Ni Cristo na July 27 ay idedeklara itong non-working holiday.

Ang pagpapasa sa panukala ay isinagawa kaalinsabay ng ika-103 taong anibersaryo ng INC na inaprubahan ng may 242 kongresista.

Ang panukalang ito ay pinagsama-samang panukala nina Reps. Winston Castelo (PDP-Laban, Quezon City); Alfred Vargas (PDP-Laban, QC); Eugene de Vera (ABS Partylist); Gil P. Acosta (NP, Palawan); Gus Tambunting (PDP-Laban, Parañaque City) at Romeo Acop (LP, Antipolo City).

Sinabi ni Castelo na inaamyendahan ng HB 5686 ang Republic Act No. 9645 o mas kilala bilang Commemoration of the Founding Anniversary of Iglesia Ni Cristo Act, sa pamamagitan ng pagdedeklara ng July 27 bilang non-working holiday.

Paliwanag ni Castelo, chairman ng House Committee on Metro Manila Development, ito’y upang mabigyan ng pagkakataon ang mga Pilipino na miembro ng INC na maipagdiwang ang anibersaryo tuwing July 27.

Samantala, naipasa na sa Committee on Rules ang House Resolution 1163 na nagpapahatid ng pagbati sa ika-103 anibersaryo ng Iglesia Ni Cristo nitong nagdaang July 27, 2017 at ang House Resolution 1167 na nagpapahatid naman ng pagbati sa walong taong matagumpay na pangunguna ni Iglesia Ni Cristo Executive Minister Eduardo V. Manalo.

INC anniversary bilang non-working holiday, pasado sa Kamara

INAPRUBAHAN na sa ikatlo at huling pagbasa ang panukalang batas na ibilang na special non-working holiday ang anibersaryo ng Iglesia ni Cristo (INC).

Batay sa House Bill 5686, tuwing anibersaryo ng Iglesia Ni Cristo na July 27 ay idedeklara itong non-working holiday.

Ang pagpapasa sa panukala ay isinagawa kaalinsabay ng ika-103 taong anibersaryo ng INC na inaprubahan ng may 242 kongresista.

Ang panukalang ito ay pinagsama-samang panukala nina Reps. Winston Castelo (PDP-Laban, Quezon City); Alfred Vargas (PDP-Laban, QC); Eugene de Vera (ABS Partylist); Gil P. Acosta (NP, Palawan); Gus Tambunting (PDP-Laban, Parañaque City) at Romeo Acop (LP, Antipolo City).

Sinabi ni Castelo na inaamyendahan ng HB 5686 ang Republic Act No. 9645 o mas kilala bilang Commemoration of the Founding Anniversary of Iglesia Ni Cristo Act, sa pamamagitan ng pagdedeklara ng July 27 bilang non-working holiday.

Paliwanag ni Castelo, chairman ng House Committee on Metro Manila Development, ito’y upang mabigyan ng pagkakataon ang mga Pilipino na miembro ng INC na maipagdiwang ang anibersaryo tuwing July 27.

Samantala, naipasa na sa Committee on Rules ang House Resolution 1163 na nagpapahatid ng pagbati sa ika-103 anibersaryo ng Iglesia Ni Cristo nitong nagdaang July 27, 2017 at ang House Resolution 1167 na nagpapahatid naman ng pagbati sa walong taong matagumpay na pangunguna ni Iglesia Ni Cristo Executive Minister Eduardo V. Manalo.

column31: 23 September 2019 Youth and Sports Committee Meeting The House Committee on Youth and Sports Development chaired by Rep. Eric Martinez (2nd District, Valenzuela City) on Monday held its organizational meeting to discuss and approve its rules of procedure. The committee was also apprised by Philippine Sports Commission Chairman William Ramirez on the preparations for the 30th Southeast Asian Games to be held in Manila from November 30 to December 10, 2019. Martinez asked if the P7.5 billion budget for the SEAG preparations will guarantee the overall championship of the Philippines in the sports event. He cited that in 1991, host Philippines emerged as the overall champion of the SEAG. Ramirez said the heart and soul of the SEAG is the athletes. He also clarified that the SEAG budget was slashed by the Senate from P7.5 billion to P6 billion and eventually to P5 billion. Ramirez said through the initiative of House Speaker Alan Peter "Compañero" Cayetano, an additional P1 billion was raised to keep the budget at P6 billion. The Speaker is Chairman of the Philippine Southeast Asian Games Organizing Committee (PHISGOC). http://www.congress.gov.ph/photojournal/zoom.php?photoid=2130 Things that was discussed: 1.Proposed Rules of Procedure of the Committee on Youth and Sports Development 2. Sports athletes/competitions commendation of the House 3. 30th SEA Games For the 30th South East Asian Games, Philippine Sports Commission Issue(s): Procurement of equipment (they will rent instead & it will reflect on their MOOE) Several sponsors pitched in to discuss the ff: TEMPLATE THAT WAS USED BY THE GOVT. (They used what the Asian Continental Games look and operates. It will have an Asian games quality, 11,000 officials and athletes; 9,000 volunteers to run and operate the program.) VENUES PLACEMENT. (Since 1934, this is the only time that PH will have its own facilities, its still far from the likes of Singapore or Thailand but, they are getting there.) TEST VENUES. (2 test venues in Clark, but it is only in La Union where the surfing events can be conducted, everything was pursuant to International Standards) PROCUREMENT STATUS. (P 3.3 Billion pesos allotment, 30 are moving and out of that 30, 2 were already awarded for the designs, P 300 M for the venues technical requirements, business uniforms, casual uniforms, etc. were awarded as well) MARKETING. (There will be billboard signage, promoting the SEA Games, local district representatives were also asked to help with the promotion, by October 1, they will air TV commercials to Major TV networks, by the 15th, it will be the awarding for procurement services, livestreaming of some 11 sports while others will get highlights) ATHLETES VILLAGE. (furnishing only e.g. painting of doors etc.) FOOD. (they have a master plan for catering, whereas halal food will also be served especially to members of the Islamic Community) TICKETS. (General admission worth 50 pesos, they will also try to persuade LGUs to have them invite students to watch the games) BY OCTOBER 15, EVERYTHING WILL BE GOOD TO GO.

Ang panukalang ito ay pinagsama-samang panukala nina Reps. Winston Castelo (PDP-Laban, Quezon City); Alfred Vargas (PDP-Laban, QC); Eugene de Vera (ABS Partylist); Gil P. Acosta (NP, Palawan); Gus Tambunting (PDP-Laban, Parañaque City) at Romeo Acop (LP, Antipolo City).

The House Committee on People’s Participation chaired by San Jose Del Monte City Rep. Florida Robes held an online discussion Thursday with the Russian Federation Embassy for an update on the status of Russia’s vaccine for COVID-19. In her opening remarks, Robes said achieving the goal of immunizing Filipinos against the COVID-19 disease to definite courses of government action has become more imperative not only for the country to recover from the economic slump but to save lives as well. She stressed the importance of people’s participation in the COVID-19 vaccination program. “Dahil ang people’s participation ay naguugnay sa lahat ng klase ng tao, mayaman man o mahirap, at higit sa lahat, ang civil society o ang nasa gobyerno,” she said.
